alt_statements.statement: At 82, I’ve seen how new tools can change lives, and I think artificial intelligence should be used to make our communities fairer, healthier, and more supportive—especially for seniors, people with disabilities, and those who’ve been left out. But we can’t just trust the tech companies to police themselves; we need strong, democratic oversight, transparent rules, and public input to prevent abuse, protect privacy, and make sure AI is used to help people, not replace or exploit them.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life more efficient and reliable, especially in areas like medicine, where it can help reduce errors and support professionals, not replace them. At the same time, we need strict, enforceable regulations to prevent abuses, protect privacy, and make sure tech companies can’t just do whatever they want with people’s data. I’d want elected officials—not unelected tech elites—setting clear rules and accountability, with a strong focus on keeping families, jobs, and basic moral values safe.

As a physical therapist, I see AI as a powerful tool to improve access to care, personalize treatment, and free clinicians from paperwork so we can spend more time with patients, not less. But because the stakes are high—people’s health, jobs, and privacy—we need strong, democratic oversight: transparent algorithms, strict bias testing, data protections, and meaningful input from frontline workers and patients in how systems are designed and deployed.

Creo que la inteligencia artificial puede ser una herramienta útil para hacer el trabajo más eficiente, ayudar en la medicina y mejorar servicios básicos, siempre y cuando no reemplace la dignidad ni el sustento de las personas trabajadoras. Me preocupa que pueda quitar empleos a gente sencilla como yo, o que se use para vigilar o manipular a la población, así que el gobierno y las empresas deben poner reglas claras, responsables y con supervisión humana. Desde mis valores cristianos, pienso que la tecnología debe servir a la persona, proteger a los más vulnerables y respetar la libertad y la privacidad.

As someone who works in a hospital and sees both the promise and the limits of technology every day, I think artificial intelligence should be used to support human judgment, not replace it—especially in areas that affect people’s health, safety, and basic rights. AI can be a powerful tool for improving care, efficiency, and access to information, but it needs strong, transparent oversight that includes clear accountability when things go wrong, protections against bias, and meaningful input from the communities it affects.

I think artificial intelligence should be used mainly as a tool to make life easier and work more efficient, but not as a replacement for human judgment or responsibility. It ought to be transparent and tested carefully, especially when it affects people’s jobs, privacy, or access to services. Rules and oversight should come from a mix of government, independent experts, and the public, so no one group has too much control. Overall, I’d like to see steady, practical progress with clear safeguards rather than rushing ahead and cleaning up the mess later.

As someone who works in insurance claims and sees how messy real-life situations can be, I think AI should be used as a powerful decision-support tool, not a replacement for human judgment or accountability. I want AI systems to be transparent, audited regularly for bias and error, and regulated like other high-impact industries—more like financial or safety oversight than vague “self-regulation.” We should prioritize using AI to expand access to services, reduce drudgery, and improve fairness, but always with legally enforceable guardrails, clear avenues for appeal, and protections for workers and vulnerable communities.

As a student who cares a lot about the environment and my community, I think artificial intelligence should be used to solve big problems like climate change, healthcare access, and education inequality, not just to make corporations richer. But because AI can be biased, invade privacy, and put people’s jobs at risk, we need strong democratic oversight—clear laws, transparency about how systems work, and protections for workers and vulnerable groups. I believe regular people, not just tech companies and politicians, should have a voice in how AI is developed and used.

As someone who supervises people every day, I think artificial intelligence should be used to support human workers, not replace them—making jobs safer, services more efficient, and information more accessible, especially for immigrants and working families. But because powerful tools can be abused, we need strong, democratically accountable regulations that protect privacy, prevent discrimination, and ensure corporations and the government cannot use AI to exploit or surveil vulnerable communities.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life more efficient and productive, especially in business, healthcare, and education, but it should never replace human responsibility or common sense. I’m excited about the practical benefits—better tools at work, safer products, smarter services—but I believe its development needs strong oversight from both the private sector and the government, with clear rules that protect jobs, privacy, families, and American values.

I think artificial intelligence should be like a super helper that makes life easier, like helping doctors, teachers, and scientists solve hard problems faster. But grown-ups should make strong rules so it can’t hurt people, take away too many jobs, or be used for lying or spying. We should always have real people in charge of the most important decisions, because people have hearts and feelings and can care about what’s fair and kind.

Artificial intelligence should be used carefully and mainly to support essential services like healthcare, public safety, and helping older people live independently, not to replace human judgment or work wherever possible. The government must set strict rules so powerful companies and foreign adversaries cannot misuse it, especially to violate privacy, manipulate elections, or undermine traditional values and religious freedoms.

I think robots and AI should help people, like making hospitals better and helping with homework, but they shouldn’t be allowed to hurt anyone or make people lose their jobs without giving them other ways to work. Grown‑ups, like teachers, parents, and leaders, should make strong rules so companies can’t use AI to spy on us, lie to us, or be unfair, and they should always remember that God made people special, so machines should never be more important than humans.

I think artificial intelligence should mostly be used to help people with big problems, like curing diseases, improving education, and protecting the environment, not just to make money or replace everyone’s jobs. Since AI can be misused or become dangerous if it gets too powerful or unfair, there should be strict rules, like how we regulate medicine or airplanes, with experts, governments, and regular people all involved in deciding what’s allowed and what isn’t.

AI should mainly be a tool to make everyday life run smoother—better traffic systems, safer cars, quicker services—not some big boss telling people what to do. I don’t want the government micromanaging it, but there should be clear, simple rules to stop big companies or the state from spying on us or wrecking people’s jobs without a plan. Let the folks who build and use this stuff be transparent and responsible, and give regular people a real say when AI affects their work or their privacy.

I think artificial intelligence ought to be used the way we’d use any powerful tool: to make everyday life run smoother, improve public services, and free people up to do work that really requires human judgment and compassion. But we’d better not just trust the tech companies to police themselves—there should be clear, enforceable rules set by elected officials, with transparency about how AI is used, especially in government, healthcare, and hiring. We need strong oversight to protect privacy, prevent bias, and make sure decisions that affect people’s lives always have a human being ultimately responsible. If we move carefully and keep regular folks’ interests at the center, AI can be helpful without running the show.

AI should be like a really smart guidebook for society: helping us navigate complex problems like climate change, education, and healthcare, but never replacing human judgment or empathy. I think we should treat it more like public infrastructure than a toy for big corporations—regulated with clear rules, transparency, and strong privacy protections, and shaped by diverse communities, not just tech bros in Silicon Valley. Since bias and surveillance are real risks, we need independent oversight, open audits of high-impact systems, and meaningful ways for people harmed by AI decisions to challenge and correct them.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life more efficient and safe, like improving healthcare, education, and business operations, but it must never replace human judgment or responsibility. We need strong, common-sense regulations that protect jobs, privacy, and national security, with strict oversight to prevent abuses by big tech and foreign governments. AI systems should be transparent, traceable, and aligned with our moral values, and there should always be a clear human being accountable for important decisions.

As someone who runs a small grocery store and spends my quiet time in the garden and watching birds, I think artificial intelligence should mostly stay in the background, helping with practical tasks like reducing waste, improving energy use, and making basic services more efficient—not replacing real human relationships or local jobs. Its risks need strong, enforceable rules set by accountable public institutions, with special protections for children, people with disabilities, and low-income families so they aren’t exploited or left behind. I’d rather see AI used to support local communities and protect the environment than to push more consumerism or surveillance.

I’ve lived long enough to see tractors turn into computers on wheels, so I know technology can make life easier if it’s kept in its place. Artificial intelligence ought to be used to help folks—like improving medical care, assisting disabled and elderly people, and making work safer—not to replace human judgment or put people out of a living. We need strict, common-sense rules, with transparency and strong oversight, so big companies and the government can’t use AI to spy on us, control speech, or rig the system. In the end, people, not machines, should stay in charge, and any AI that threatens basic freedoms or human dignity should be reined in fast.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life safer and more efficient, like improving healthcare, transportation, and even factory work, but it shouldn’t replace the dignity of honest jobs or human judgment. We need clear, enforceable rules—set by elected officials with input from regular working people, not just tech companies—to prevent abuse, protect privacy, and make sure AI doesn’t just benefit the rich. AI systems should be transparent and accountable, with strong safeguards so they can’t be used to discriminate or manipulate people. In my view, technology ought to serve human values and community well-being, not the other way around.

I think robots and computers with AI should help people, like doctors and teachers, and do boring or dangerous jobs so people can be safer and have more time for fun and family. But grown‑ups should make strong rules so AI can’t lie, be mean, or hurt people, and they should check it a lot to make sure it’s fair to everyone.

As someone who works in finance and sees both the power and the fallout of complex systems, I think AI should be used to make life more secure and fair—improving access to credit, healthcare, and information—while never replacing human judgment or compassion. We need strict, transparent regulations that treat AI like any other high-risk financial product: independently audited, stress-tested for bias and harm, and clearly explainable to the people it affects.

As someone who works every day with children’s emotional and educational needs, I see AI as a tool that should support human judgment, not replace it—especially in decisions that affect kids’ futures and mental health. I’m deeply worried about privacy, bias, and the possibility of schools or governments relying on AI to cut corners instead of investing in people, so I believe strict, transparent regulations and independent oversight are essential. AI should be used to expand access to quality education and mental health resources, but always with clear guardrails, community input, and ultimate accountability resting with humans.

Artificial intelligence should be a tool that expands opportunity—like improving education, healthcare access, and public safety—especially for communities that have historically been left behind, including Black communities in places like where I grew up. But we can’t just trust tech companies to “do the right thing”; we need strong, transparent regulations, clear accountability when systems discriminate or cause harm, and real input from everyday people, not just engineers and CEOs. Faith-wise, I believe technology should reflect basic moral principles of fairness, dignity, and compassion, which means making sure AI is used to lift people up, not to monitor, control, or replace them without support.

As a nurse and a mom, I see AI as a powerful tool that should support people, not replace the human judgment and compassion that are at the heart of good care and strong communities. It should be used to improve healthcare access, accuracy, and efficiency, and to strengthen education, but governed by strict, enforceable rules on patient privacy, bias, safety, and transparency. I want independent oversight—especially from healthcare professionals and ethicists, not just tech companies—to make sure AI is serving the public good and not just profit.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday systems more efficient and sustainable—things like smarter buildings, better energy use, and streamlining boring paperwork so people can focus on real human problems. But it can’t just be left to big companies; we need strong, enforceable regulations, transparency about how AI is used, and real protections for workers and consumers so the technology serves people and communities, not just profits.

As someone who works in pharmaceutical research, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool to accelerate drug discovery, improve diagnostics, and free up human experts to focus on judgment and empathy rather than rote analysis. But precisely because I know how much harm can come from biased data, weak oversight, or profit-driven shortcuts, I believe AI must be governed with strict, transparent regulations that prioritize public health, workers’ rights, and civil liberties over corporate interests. We should require independent audits, clear accountability for harms, and strong protections against surveillance and discrimination, especially for immigrants and marginalized communities. In a just society, AI should augment human dignity and opportunity, not replace or control people.

As someone who works in law enforcement and sees both the best and worst of people, I think AI should be used to make our communities safer and more efficient—things like better emergency response, smarter traffic systems, and tools that help us catch serious offenders without wasting time on minor stuff. But we can’t let it turn into a black box that quietly reinforces bias or invades people’s privacy, especially in communities of color like the ones I grew up in. We need strict transparency, independent oversight, clear rules about how data is used, and real consequences when companies or agencies misuse AI. If it’s going to be part of our justice system and public life, it has to be accountable to the public, not just profitable for tech companies.

I’m only little, so I don’t really understand what “artificial intelligence” is, but I know my parents and doctors help keep me safe and healthy, and I think any smart machines should be used to help them do that. Grown‑ups should make strong rules so that these machines never hurt people, especially kids, and so they’re always used to care for others, tell the truth, and be kind, the way my family and church say we should be.

I think artificial intelligence can be a powerful tool to make work safer and life easier, like improving safety on construction sites, helping with healthcare, and giving more people access to good information, no solo a los ricos. But it needs strong rules so companies can’t abuse it to replace workers unfairly, invade our privacy, or spread lies and hate. The government, workers, and communities—especially Latino and working-class neighborhoods—should have a voice in making those rules, not just big tech. AI should serve people and protect our dignity, not just increase profits.

Artificial intelligence should be used to support and augment human judgment, not replace it—especially in sensitive areas like healthcare, where compassion, ethics, and accountability are essential. I believe it can be a powerful tool for improving lives and efficiency, but it must be governed through clear, conservative regulations that prioritize human dignity, privacy, and moral responsibility, with strong oversight to prevent misuse by governments, corporations, or bad actors.

Artificial intelligence should be used to boost productivity, strengthen American businesses, and support people in living healthier, more efficient lives—but it must always remain a tool, not a replacement for human judgment, responsibility, or faith. We need strong, common-sense regulations that focus on security, privacy, and preventing abuse by corporations or hostile governments, without strangling innovation with bloated bureaucracy.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to help people and the planet, like improving healthcare, education, and protecting the environment, not just to make rich companies richer. But it can be really dangerous if it spreads misinformation, replaces too many jobs, or invades people’s privacy, so I believe there should be strong laws, audits, and public oversight to keep it fair and under control. AI systems should be transparent about how they work and who’s responsible, and regular people—especially young people who’ll live with these technologies the longest—should have a say in how they’re used.

As someone who’s spent years teaching and now spends my days tending a community garden, I think artificial intelligence should serve as a tool to support people and the planet, not replace human judgment or community. I’m especially concerned about how AI might deepen inequality, harm the environment through massive energy use, and erode privacy if it’s controlled by a few powerful corporations. We need strong, democratically decided regulations that prioritize transparency, environmental impact, and protections for vulnerable groups, much like environmental laws are meant to protect our shared resources. AI should be guided by public interest and ethical principles, not just profit or technological enthusiasm.

Artificial intelligence should be used to support and protect our communities—improving public safety, healthcare, and government services—without replacing the human judgment and moral responsibility that must always come first. We need strong, common‑sense regulations that hold companies and institutions accountable, protect privacy and jobs, and ensure AI is used transparently and ethically.

Creo que los robots y la inteligencia artificial deberían ayudarnos a cuidar a las personas, como en los hospitales o en la escuela, pero siempre con un adulto responsable mirando lo que hacen. Dios nos enseña a cuidar a los demás, así que no deberían usarse para hacer daño ni para espiar a la gente. Los grandes que hacen estas cosas tienen que seguir reglas muy claras para que todos estemos seguros y nadie se quede fuera.

As an older man who’s seen a lot of change over the years, I think artificial intelligence should be used to make life safer and easier—like improving healthcare, helping seniors and people with disabilities, and making work sites and roads safer—but never to replace the dignity of honest work or human judgment. We need strong, common-sense rules, grounded in moral values and respect for privacy, so that AI is guided by people of faith and character, not just big companies or government.

Artificial intelligence should be used to support people, not replace them—improving education, healthcare, and work while respecting human dignity and responsibility. As a conservative and a Catholic, I believe we must set firm moral and legal boundaries: protect privacy, prevent abuse by big corporations and government, and always keep humans accountable for decisions that affect lives. Powerful AI systems need strict oversight, clear transparency, and real consequences when they cause harm, so that innovation serves families and communities rather than undermining them.

As someone who advises young people about their futures and cares deeply about the environment, I think AI should be used as a practical tool to support human decision-making, especially in areas like education, public services, and climate and wildlife protection—not as a replacement for human judgment or relationships. Its risks should be governed through strong, enforceable public regulations that prioritize transparency, strict limits on surveillance and corporate control, and meaningful input from everyday citizens and frontline workers, not just tech companies and politicians.

I think AI should be used to make everyday life easier and fairer, like improving healthcare, education, and jobs for regular people, not just tech companies and the rich. But because it can also cost people their jobs, spread misinformation, and bias against folks like me, we need strong government rules, transparency, and community oversight to keep it in check. As a Catholic and a Democrat, I believe AI should always respect human dignity first, and decisions about it should involve diverse voices, especially workers and marginalized communities.

Artificial intelligence should be a tool that boosts human productivity and creativity, not something that replaces our judgment or freedom. I’m all for businesses using AI to cut waste, improve safety, and give people more time for meaningful work, but it has to stay transparent and optional—folks should know when it’s being used and be able to opt out. The government’s role should be limited to setting clear rules against abuse—like mass surveillance, discrimination, or monopolies—while leaving room for innovation and personal responsibility. In the end, people, not algorithms, should be accountable for big decisions that affect lives and livelihoods.

I think robots and AI should help people, like doctors and teachers, so things are easier and safer for everyone. But grown‑ups, like the government and smart scientists, should make strong rules so AI can’t hurt people or lie, and so kids like me can stay safe when we use it.

I think artificial intelligence should help people with important things like school, medicine, and protecting the environment, but it shouldn’t replace real human teachers, doctors, or parents. Grown-ups, especially honest leaders and smart scientists, should make strict rules so AI can’t be used to hurt people, lie, or spy on us all the time. AI should be a tool God lets us use wisely to help others, not something we worship or let control our lives.

Artificial intelligence should be treated like any powerful public infrastructure: developed openly, audited rigorously, and steered toward expanding access to education, healthcare, and economic opportunity, especially for communities that have historically been marginalized. At the same time, we need strong, enforceable regulations—independent oversight, civil-rights protections, transparency requirements, and clear lines of accountability—so that AI systems can’t quietly entrench bias, erode privacy, or concentrate power in the hands of a few corporations or governments.

As a dental hygienist and a mom, I see AI as a tool that should make everyday life and work safer, more efficient, and more personalized—whether that’s improving patient care in the dental office or helping kids learn at school. But I also worry about privacy, job security, and mental health if we move too fast without guardrails. I think we need clear, enforceable regulations, developed by a mix of experts, everyday workers, and community members, to ensure AI is transparent, accountable, and used to support human judgment rather than replace it.

As someone who uses tech every day but still worries about how it affects my kids’ future, I think artificial intelligence should be used to make life easier and fairer—like improving healthcare, education, and accessibility for people with disabilities—without replacing the human judgment and compassion that really matter. We need strong, transparent rules set by government and independent experts, not just big companies, to prevent abuse, protect privacy and jobs, and make sure the benefits of AI are shared widely, not just concentrated at the top.

As someone who spent her life teaching and now volunteers at the library, I see artificial intelligence as a tool that should help people learn, stay healthy, and care for our environment—not replace our human judgment or compassion. I believe it must be closely regulated, with clear rules to protect privacy, prevent abuse and job exploitation, and ensure it serves the common good rather than just corporate profit. Lawmakers, educators, faith leaders, and everyday citizens should all have a say in how it’s used so it reflects our shared moral values and responsibilities to one another.

As someone who works in holistic healthcare, I see artificial intelligence as a tool that should support human well-being, not replace human judgment, intuition, and compassion. AI can be incredibly helpful for analyzing data, improving access to care, and handling routine tasks, but decisions that affect people’s bodies, livelihoods, and communities must remain grounded in human ethics and personal responsibility. Its risks should be governed through strong, transparent regulations, public oversight, and protections against corporate abuse and bias, with special attention to privacy and the dignity of each person. Above all, we need to ensure AI serves the common good, not just profit or convenience.

I think artificial intelligence should mostly be used to help people, like making hospitals better, schools more fun to learn in, and protecting the environment, but not to replace humans or make us lazier or meaner to each other. Adults and governments should make strict rules so AI can’t hurt people, lie to them, or spy on them too much, and they should always have real humans checking what the AI does.

I think artificial intelligence should be used mainly to make everyday life easier and fairer—like improving healthcare, education, and public services—rather than just helping big companies cut jobs or boost profits. We need strong, transparent rules, almost like consumer and workplace protections, to prevent AI from worsening inequality, spreading misinformation, or invading privacy. Regular people, not just tech executives and politicians, should have a voice in shaping those rules so the technology actually serves communities.

As a healthcare professional and a parent, I see enormous potential for AI to improve lives—whether it’s helping diagnose conditions earlier, personalizing rehab programs, or freeing up time so I can focus more on human connection with my patients and my family. But AI should be treated like any powerful medical tool: it needs rigorous, transparent regulation, independent oversight, and clear accountability to prevent abuse, protect privacy, and avoid deepening inequalities.

As someone who works in law enforcement and cares about keeping my community safe, I see AI as a powerful tool that can help us prevent crime, respond faster in emergencies, and use taxpayer money more efficiently. But it should always be under strict human oversight, with clear laws, transparency, and accountability so it doesn’t trample on civil liberties or concentrate too much power in the hands of big tech or government. I support strong regulations that focus on real-world risks—like bias, privacy violations, and loss of control—without smothering innovation that can genuinely improve public safety and quality of life.

As a working mom and community volunteer, I see AI as a powerful tool that should make everyday life fairer and more efficient—whether that’s improving access to housing, health care, or education—without replacing real human judgment and compassion. But we can’t just trust the market to sort it out: AI needs strong, transparent oversight, clear rules against discrimination, and accountability when things go wrong, especially for vulnerable communities.

My mommy says computers can be very helpful if people use them kindly, like helping doctors and teachers and making work easier. I think grown‑ups should make strong rules so the computers don’t hurt people or make anyone feel left out, and they should always remember God wants us to take care of each other first.

I think AI should mostly help people with boring or hard jobs, like checking lots of information fast or helping doctors and teachers, so humans have more time to be creative and with family. But adults should make strong rules so AI can’t be used to cheat, lie, or hurt people, and companies shouldn’t be allowed to just do anything they want with it. I’d feel safer if there were clear laws and teachers explaining how it works, so kids like me know what’s real and what’s not online.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to make life fairer and easier for people, like improving schools, healthcare, and helping families who don’t have a lot of money or support. But since AI can also be biased and make mistakes that hurt people who look like me, there need to be strict rules, diverse people testing it, and real consequences when companies or governments use it in unfair or harmful ways.

At my age, I’ve seen how new technologies can both ease suffering and deepen inequality, and I think artificial intelligence should be used first and foremost to improve people’s lives—especially in areas like healthcare, elder care, and education—without ever replacing the human touch. We need strong, democratically accountable rules that make companies transparent about how their systems work, prevent bias and surveillance, and put the needs of ordinary people above profit.

As someone who works in manufacturing and cares a lot about both efficiency and well-being, I see AI as a powerful tool that should support people rather than replace them, especially in repetitive or dangerous tasks. But because the risks—like job loss, bias, and surveillance—are real, we need strong, transparent regulations, worker protections, and community input, not just decisions made in boardrooms. AI systems should be audited for fairness and environmental impact, and ordinary people, including immigrants and frontline workers, should have a voice in how these technologies are designed and deployed.

As someone who works with my hands every day and cares a lot about providing for my family, I think AI should be a tool that makes work safer, more efficient, and more accessible for people with disabilities, not a way to replace us or strip away our dignity. AI needs strong, transparent rules—like safety standards in trucking—so companies can’t misuse it to invade privacy, deepen inequality, or harm the environment, and regular workers, disabled folks, and communities get a real say in how it’s designed and used.

As a retired man who came from Mexico and worked hard his whole life, I see artificial intelligence as a tool that should help people, not replace them—especially older folks, workers, and those who struggle with language or disabilities. I think AI needs strong rules, like safety checks and clear accountability, so big companies and the government can’t use it to spy on us, spread lies, or take away jobs without protections. Churches, local communities, and families should have a say in how AI is used, so it respects our faith, our privacy, and our freedoms.

As an attorney and a liberal, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that can expand access to justice, improve public services, and drive innovation, but only if it operates within a robust framework of the rule of law. We need clear statutory and regulatory safeguards on data privacy, bias, accountability, and transparency, with meaningful avenues for redress when harms occur. AI systems that affect rights, livelihoods, or public safety should be subject to rigorous testing, independent oversight, and ongoing public scrutiny, not just left to corporate self-regulation.

I think robots and smart computers should help people be safe and happy, like helping doctors and teachers and making hard things easier. But grown-ups need to watch them very carefully, like how my parents and teachers watch me, so they don’t hurt people, lie, or make anyone feel left out.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to help people live better lives, like improving healthcare, education, and making things more fair for everyone, especially for communities that are often left out, like Black communities. But it needs strong rules so it can’t be used to spy on people, spread hate, or take away jobs without giving people support and new opportunities. AI should be checked for bias, and regular people—not just big companies—should have a say in how it’s used. From my faith and values, I believe it should always respect human dignity and never replace real human care and responsibility.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make life easier and safer for families, like improving medicine, education, and public safety, but it must never replace the value of human work, faith, and personal responsibility. The government should set strict, common‑sense rules so AI can’t be used to spy on people, spread lies, or harm children, and tech companies must be held accountable when they put profit over people. AI decisions that affect our rights, jobs, or safety should always have human oversight, and we should protect traditional values and personal freedom as we move forward with this technology.

Artificial intelligence should be used to ease human suffering and expand access to education, healthcare, and the arts, not to replace the dignity of human work or the depth of human creativity. We need strong, transparent regulations and independent oversight so AI can’t be used to manipulate voters, deepen inequality, or strip away privacy. As a Catholic and a liberal, I believe we’re morally obligated to ensure AI serves the common good, especially the poor and vulnerable, rather than the narrow interests of powerful companies.

I think AI should mostly be used to help people with everyday stuff, like making schoolwork easier to understand, improving healthcare, and keeping communities safer, but not to replace real human jobs and relationships. Grown-ups and experts should have strict rules and laws to make sure AI doesn’t lie, invade our privacy, or get used in ways that hurt people or spread unfairness. Since kids like me will grow up with this tech, we should also be taught how it works and what’s risky about it, so we can speak up if something seems wrong.

I think robots and computers that can think should help people, like making things easier at hospitals and schools, but grown-ups should always be in charge of them. My mom and the people at church say we have to be careful with powerful things, so I think there should be rules so AI can’t be mean, lie, or hurt people’s jobs or feelings.

Artificial intelligence should be used mainly to make work safer, faster, and more efficient, not to replace hardworking people or undermine basic human judgment and common sense. We need strict, practical rules—set by elected officials, not tech companies—that protect privacy, prevent abuse by big government or corporations, and keep things like weapons and critical infrastructure under tight human control. Any AI that affects jobs, safety, or personal freedoms should be watched closely and held accountable, just like any other powerful tool.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to solve real problems like climate change, healthcare access, and education, not just to make companies richer or replace workers without support. The government, scientists, and regular people should all have a say in how AI is developed and used, with clear accountability when things go wrong.

I think artificial intelligence should mainly be used to make everyday life easier and fairer, like improving healthcare, public services, and access to information, not just to help big companies make more money. Government, not just tech companies, should set those rules, and regular people should have a say in what’s allowed and what isn’t.

Artificial intelligence should be used as a practical tool to make society safer, more efficient, and more accountable, especially in areas like law enforcement, emergency response, and public administration. But it needs strict oversight, clear rules, and real human responsibility behind every major decision so we don’t end up with unaccountable systems or violations of people’s rights. I’d support strong regulations, transparency requirements, and tough penalties for abuse or negligence, rather than letting big tech or the federal bureaucracy set the rules on their own.

I think artificial intelligence can be useful for practical things like better medical care, safer cars, and making everyday work a little easier, but it should never replace real human judgment, especially when it comes to family, faith, and community. We need strong laws and clear rules to keep big companies and the government from using AI to spy on people, spread lies, or take away jobs without protections. Any use of AI should respect our basic rights, our privacy, and our values, and we should always have real people in charge who can be held accountable when something goes wrong.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to make life easier and fairer for people, like improving healthcare, education, and helping fight climate change, not just to help big companies make more money. But because AI can spread misinformation, invade privacy, and make biased decisions, we need strong rules that are transparent, science-based, and focused on protecting regular people and the planet. Lawmakers should have to explain how AI is being used, allow independent audits, and give people the right to challenge harmful decisions made by algorithms.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make life easier and safer for people—especially seniors—by improving healthcare, public safety, and basic services, not by replacing human contact or common-sense decision making. It needs strong, clear rules from our government, with transparency about how it’s used, so that it respects our privacy, protects our jobs, and upholds our moral and religious values.

Artificial intelligence should be treated as a powerful public utility: it can expand access to education, streamline public services, and free people from repetitive work, but only if it’s developed and deployed under strong democratic oversight rather than left to corporate interests alone. We need clear, enforceable regulations around transparency, data use, accountability for harms, and labor impacts, along with independent public bodies that can audit high‑risk systems and halt their use when necessary.

As someone who works with people every day, I see AI as a tool that should make life easier and fairer—helping with things like billing, energy use, healthcare access, and public services—without replacing the human connection and judgment that real communities need. But because technology often ignores or harms Black people, immigrants, and those without power, AI must be tightly regulated: algorithms audited for bias, decisions made transparent, workers protected from displacement, and communities—especially marginalized ones—given a real voice in how these systems are designed and used.

As a designer, I see AI as a powerful tool for augmenting human creativity, not replacing it—helping with the tedious stuff so people have more space to imagine, question, and express. As someone who has lived long enough to see many new technologies come and go, I believe artificial intelligence should be used carefully to assist people, not replace them, especially in areas like education, healthcare, and services for the elderly. AI should be used like any powerful tool: to make everyday life easier, safer, and more efficient, especially in areas like healthcare, transportation, and boring repetitive work, but never to replace basic human judgment or connection. I think we need clear, common-sense rules set by a mix of experts, government, and regular workers so companies can’t just do whatever they want with our data or jobs. I think AI should be used to make life easier and fairer for people, like helping with school, healthcare, and boring or dangerous jobs, not just to make rich companies richer. I think robots and computers that can think a little bit should help people, like doctors and teachers, so things are easier and faster. I think robots and smart computers should help people with hard jobs, like fixing big problems or keeping us safe, but they shouldn’t be the boss of everything. I think artificial intelligence should be used mainly to make practical tasks easier—like improving medical care, keeping factories safer and more efficient, and helping older people live independently—but not to replace human judgment, especially in moral or family matters. The government, working with honest experts and industry, should set firm rules to protect privacy, prevent abuse, and make sure AI doesn’t take away people’s dignity or ability to work, while keeping America strong and competitive in the world.

I think robots and computers that can think, like AI, should mostly help people, like making it easier to learn, keeping us safe, and maybe even helping sick people get better. But grown-ups need to make strong rules so AI can’t be used to hurt people, lie to them, or be unfair, and they should keep checking it, kind of like how parents and teachers watch kids on the playground to make sure everyone is safe and sharing.

As someone who’s spent a career helping people navigate complex real estate decisions, I see AI as a powerful tool that can make life more efficient and fair—whether that’s streamlining paperwork, improving access to information, or helping us tackle big issues like climate change and housing affordability. But given how easily systems can inherit bias and be misused by corporations or government, we need strong, transparent regulations, public oversight, and clear accountability so AI serves people, not the other way around.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make businesses more efficient, create good-paying jobs, and improve everyday life, but it should never replace personal responsibility, human judgment, or family values. We need strong, commonsense regulations focused on safety, privacy, and preventing abuse—especially by big tech and foreign adversaries—without strangling innovation that keeps America competitive. AI should support workers, not exploit them, and its development should be guided by ethical standards rooted in respect for human dignity and our faith-based values.

As a special education teacher and a mom, I see AI as a powerful tool that should help us create more inclusive classrooms, better public services, and fairer opportunities—especially for kids and families who are often overlooked. But because it can also amplify bias and concentrate power, AI needs strong democratic oversight: transparent rules, community input (including from immigrants and people with disabilities), and firm protections for privacy, workers’ rights, and human dignity.

As a nurse, I see AI as a powerful tool to augment human judgment, not replace it—especially in healthcare, where it can improve diagnostics, reduce burnout, and free us to spend more time actually caring for patients. But I don’t trust corporations or governments to self-police something this consequential, so we need strict, enforceable regulations, transparency about how systems work, and real accountability when they cause harm or amplify bias. AI should be developed and governed with input from frontline workers and impacted communities, not just tech executives, so that it serves public health and equity rather than profit alone.

As someone who works with complex industrial equipment and cares deeply about the world my kids will grow up in, I see AI as a powerful tool that should be used to make work safer, cut pollution, and improve people’s everyday lives, not to replace human dignity or judgment. But because mistakes in tech can have real consequences—especially for workers, the environment, and marginalized communities—we need strong, transparent rules, democratic oversight, and independent audits to keep corporations and governments from abusing it.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to help people with everyday stuff, like making school easier to understand, helping doctors, and keeping us safer, but not to replace people or make us feel watched all the time. Grown-ups and experts should make strict rules so companies can’t use AI to lie, steal people’s ideas, or be unfair to certain groups, and they should explain the rules in simple words so kids and families like mine can understand what’s going on.

At my age, I’ve seen technology change the world many times over, and I think artificial intelligence should be used to make life fairer, greener, and safer—whether that’s improving education, healthcare, or how we manage our resources and protect the environment. But powerful tools need strong guardrails: we ought to have clear, democratically shaped rules that prevent AI from deepening inequality, invading privacy, or replacing human judgment and compassion where they matter most.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life easier and fairer, especially in areas like healthcare, senior services, and community programs, but never at the expense of people’s dignity or jobs. We need strong, transparent regulations—like safety checks, bias audits, and clear rules about data privacy—so that big corporations and the government can’t abuse these tools. AI should support human judgment, not replace it, and ordinary folks, especially those of us who are older or disabled, deserve a say in how it’s designed and used.

As someone who has spent a lifetime studying complex environmental systems, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that should be deployed in service of the common good—improving climate modeling, monitoring ecosystems, and informing evidence-based policy, not maximizing short-term profit. But like any potent technology, it demands robust, democratically accountable governance: strict transparency and safety standards, public oversight boards that include ethicists, scientists, and affected communities, and legal guardrails to prevent exploitation, surveillance abuses, and the exacerbation of existing social and environmental inequities.

I think artificial intelligence ought to be a tool that helps people work smarter, not something that replaces honest, hard‑working folks or makes us dependent on big tech companies. We need commonsense regulations that protect privacy, prevent abuse by government and corporations, and keep decisions about how AI is used close to local communities, not distant bureaucrats. Above all, AI should never undermine our personal responsibility, faith, or freedoms—it should stay in its lane as a helpful assistant, not a moral or political authority.

As someone who works in a recording studio and sees how tech is reshaping creativity, I think AI should be used as a tool to expand human expression and make opportunities more accessible, not to replace people’s livelihoods or judgment. We need strong, enforceable regulations—like transparency requirements, bias audits, and labor protections—so that AI doesn’t deepen inequality or concentrate power in a few corporations. I’d like to see democratic oversight and public input guide how AI is deployed, with special attention to protecting privacy, mental health, and the rights of artists and workers.

I think AI can be really helpful, like making school and work easier and opening up new jobs, but it shouldn’t be running everything or deciding people’s futures on its own. There needs to be strict rules so it doesn’t make things more unfair for Black people or poor communities, and regular folks should have a say in how it’s used, not just big companies and the government.

Artificial intelligence ought to serve as a tool that makes people’s lives safer, healthier, and more efficient, not as a replacement for human judgment, responsibility, or dignity. We should have strong, enforceable regulations—much like the rules and oversight we rely on in the insurance industry—to ensure transparency, protect privacy, prevent abuse by big corporations or government, and hold people accountable when AI causes harm. At the same time, we shouldn’t smother innovation; we should encourage uses of AI that respect human life, family, faith, and individual liberty.

As a teacher and a Catholic, I think artificial intelligence should serve people, not replace them, by taking over routine tasks so we can focus more on human relationships, critical thinking, and care for our communities and the environment. We need strong, transparent public oversight—through democratic institutions, not just tech companies—to make sure AI doesn’t deepen inequality, spread misinformation, or exploit students’ data.

As a teacher who cares deeply about social justice and the environment, I think AI should be used to expand access to education, improve public services, and help us tackle big challenges like climate change—not to replace human relationships or judgment. But those benefits only matter if AI is governed with strong public oversight, transparency, and accountability, with diverse communities at the table so that algorithms don’t reinforce existing inequalities.
